prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our proposed observations will measure 12CO, 13CO, and the continuum at 1.3mm in order to study the gas and dust content of very low-mass TWA members. We elect to use Band 6 for this proposal given that weather conditions more often allow high-quality observations at 230 GHz than at 345 GHz, despite the fact that cold dust grains may be brighter at 850microns than at 1.3mm. For other nearby molecular gas disks, 12CO(2-1) emission is comparable that the J=3-2 transition.
Requested sensitivity: In order to detect the potentially small amount of CO gas in these system, we aim to reach a sensitivity of 5 mJy per 0.6 km/s channel. With an emission line width of about 3 km/s, this implies an integrated line sensitivity of 7 mJy km/s. By having both 12CO and 13CO measurements, we can estimate the optical depth of 12CO emission. With some basic assumptions (see Scientific Justification), we estimate we can detect a gas mass content of 0.005 Earth masses at 5-sigma.
Several systems in our sample have indications of infrared excesses and thus of dust disks surrounding them. Warm WISE-detected dust grains can have 1.3mm emission of order 0.1 mJy or fainter. Cold dust grains, however, will significantly increase the continuum emission. For our setup, we have 5.6 GHz for continuum measurements and achieve a sensitivity of 0.05 mJy. This serves as an extra data point to help characterize the warm (T~200 K) dust grains and is sufficient to detect any cold dust in the system to a 5-sigma limit of about 0.03 Earth masses (assuming optically thin, T=30 K dust grains).
Imaging requirements: For this proposal we do not aim to resolve any disks. We thus request the 1.6-arcsecond angular resolution of the most compact array for Band 6 (C34-1). The maximum angular scale is 11 arcseconds for this setting, but we don't expect to see any disks of that size in TWA, even if they are extended and resolved (TW Hya's 200 AU disk extends only to 4 arcseconds in radius; Qi et al.\ 2004).
Correlator setup: We have a single science goal (repeated several times to cover all targets) for both the emission lines and the continuum. This is performed in Dual polarization mode. The emission line setups consists of two spectral windows centered at 230.97 and 219.95 GHz with a bandwidth of 937.5 MHz and a resolution of 488 KHz (0.6 km/s). This permits the detection of both 12CO (230.53 GHz) and 13CO (220.39 GHz) with a single spectral setup. The remaining basebands will be used in continuum mode to provide the full coverage (2000 MHz each) at the coarsest resolution (31 MHz).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: There are precious few examples of young low-mass stars that harbor molecular gas within their circumstellar disks, yet are close enough to Earth for the sort of detailed observational studies that might constrain the conditions under which planets are born. It is essential to have a better understanding of the gaseous component of circumstellar disks as these govern how giant planets form. The ~10 Myr TW Hya Association (TWA) is an excellent group for such studies given that it is young enough to still retain some gas-rich disks (eg, TW Hya), old enough to have already formed planetary mass objects (eg, 2M1207b), and close enough (~60 pc) to permit detailed studies of its members. We propose an ALMA Band 6 survey for molecular gas disks around 15 very low-mass members of TWA, many of which will soon to be published. Our observations will be capable of detecting 12CO and 13CO line emission as well as continuum emission from cold dust in the circumstellar disks around these stars. This survey will be the definitive sample for molecular gas disks among ultracool dwarfs and will lead to a greater understanding of planet formation and evolution around low-mass stars and brown dwarfs.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
